results.title: Judge Ends Conservatorship Overseeing Britney Spears’s Life and Finances
results.abstract: The pop star had called the arrangement, which governed her life for nearly 14 years, exploitative. A judge ruled it was “no longer required.”
results.byline: By Joe Coscarelli and Julia Jacobs

multimedia.caption: Britney Spears performing in 2004.

results.title: Astroworld Disaster Rekindles Fears About Music Festival Safety
results.abstract: The concert industry notes that serious problems are still rare, but over the years a number of deadly stampedes have shown the inherent dangers of big, excited crowds.

multimedia.caption: Nine people died at Travis Scott’s Astroworld festival in Houston last week, putting a spotlight once again on safety at large concerts.
multimedia.copyright: Annie Mulligan for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Be Nice to Tourists’: New York’s Arts Scene Needs International Visitors
results.abstract: The United States now allows vaccinated international travelers into the country. It’s welcome news for arts institutions that lost revenue and cut jobs during the pandemic.

multimedia.caption: About 70 percent of the tickets at the TKTS booth in Times Square are bought by tourists and roughly half of those sales are to foreign travelers.
multimedia.copyright: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

results.title: Bruno Mars and Anderson .Paak Revisit Vintage Luxury as Silk Sonic
results.abstract: The duo gleefully reverse-engineers the analog-era sophistication of 1970s R&B on a new album, “An Evening With Silk Sonic.”

multimedia.caption: Anderson .Paak and Bruno Mars revisit the bygone analog era of 1970s R&B on a new collaborative album.

results.title: ‘I Don’t Know What a Carrie Is’: Candace Bushnell Works It Out Onstage
results.abstract: The writer maps her life in a one-woman show, “Is There Still Sex in the City?,” beginning previews this weekend at the Daryl Roth Theater.
des_facet: Is There Still Sex in the City? (Play)

multimedia.caption: Candace Bushnell at the Carlyle Hotel recently. She said she was a bit unnerved during the first performances of her show, which had a tryout at Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa.
multimedia.copyright: Celeste Sloman for The New York Times

results.title: Hong Kong’s M+ Museum Is Finally Open. It’s Already in Danger.
results.abstract: The museum, billed as Asia’s premier art institution, faced construction delays and personnel problems. Now it faces its greatest challenge: the threat of censorship.

multimedia.caption: As the M+ Museum in Hong Kong opened on Friday, its greatest challenge was just materializing: the threat of censorship from the Chinese Communist Party.

results.title: He Stalks Delirious, Unfinished New York as It Rises
results.abstract: Nick Relph’s new book, “Eclipse Body & Soul Syntax,” collects years of digital street scans of New York City construction posters, an eerie portrait of a supersizing metropolis.

multimedia.caption: The artist Nick Relph at a construction site in Brooklyn, where residential towers are rising everywhere. He has spent seven years scanning renderings of buildings on construction posters, which are collected in a new book.
multimedia.copyright: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times

results.title: The Stakes Are Sky-High for a ‘Ring’ Coming to the Met Opera
results.abstract: For Richard Jones, the director of a staging that will open in London and later travel to New York, this is a third attempt at Wagner’s epic.

multimedia.caption: The “Ring” is “a monstrous, pulsating, ambiguous, big, queer thing,” Jones said.
multimedia.copyright: Kalpesh Lathigra for The New York Times

results.title: Review: The Cellist Sheku Kanneh-Mason Makes an Entrance
results.abstract: A young star made his New York Philharmonic debut in an evening of bold, charismatic musical storytelling.

multimedia.caption: Simone Young conducts the New York Philharmonic with Sheku Kanneh-Mason making his debut at Alice Tully Hall, 11/11/2021

results.title: The Show Goes On, Even After China Tried to Shut It Down
results.abstract: An Italian city rejected a request from the Chinese Embassy in Rome to cancel an exhibition by Badiucao, an artist who has been described as the Chinese Banksy.

multimedia.caption: Badiucao in front of one of his works, “Carrie Lam,” a portrait of Hong Kong’s chief executive, at Santa Giulia Museum in Brescia, Italy.
multimedia.copyright: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times

results.title: Review: Young Concert Artists Is Back, With a Superb Pianist
results.abstract: Zhu Wang played an unusually interesting and adventurous set of pieces at Zankel Hall.

multimedia.caption: The pianist Zhu Wang made his New York debut with a recital on Thursday at Zankel Hall, presented by Young Concert Artists.
multimedia.copyright: Caitlin Ochs for The New York Times

results.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: This month’s picks include mutants in love and mushrooms out for blood.
des_facet: Horror Noire: A History of Black Horror (Movie)
Nobody Sleeps in the Woods Tonight 2 (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Eric Tabach in “Dashcam.”

results.title: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
results.abstract: The hosts had plenty to talk about this week, including President Biden's approval rating and Big Bird's vaccination status.

results.title: 5 Songs to Listen to Right Now
results.abstract: I write about pop music for The New York Times. Here are five new and notable songs, including Kylie Minogue and Jessie Ware’s duet and TNGHT’s return.

results.title: ‘Alpha,’ by David Philipps: A Navy SEAL’s Behavior Worried Teammates and Changed How They Fought
results.abstract: In a new book, a Times reporter details the SEALs culture that fostered Eddie Gallagher’s rise and sheds new light on the events that led to his trial (and acquittal) in a polarizing war crimes case.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: Navy Special Operations Chief Edward Gallagher arriving at military court at Naval Base San Diego in June 2019. Chief Gallagher, who was on trial for war crimes, was acquitted on the most serious charges.

results.title: Review: Theater Professors Are Under the Gun in ‘Preparedness’
results.abstract: In this workplace comedy, beleaguered colleagues struggle to come together for an active-shooter training exercise.

multimedia.caption: As part of the “Preparedness” training, Alison Cimmet, second from right, shows a simulated emergency to the theater professors played by (from left) Luis Moreno, KK Moggie, Nora Cole, Lou Liberatore and Tracy Hazas.

results.title: Experts said it was unusual to end a conservatorship without a mental health screening.
results.abstract: Britney Spears had asked for the arrangement to be ended without having to undergo further psychological assessments; a judge agreed.

multimedia.caption: Britney Spears in 2013.

results.title: Graeme Edge, Drummer and Co-Founder of the Moody Blues, Dies at 80
results.abstract: Many of their songs incorporated his spoken-word poetry, making them pioneers in the prog-rock movement of the late-1960s and ’70s.
org_facet: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum

multimedia.caption: Graeme Edge, left, with his fellow members of the Moody Blues, exemplars of the prog-rock movement, in 1971. The others, from left, were Ray Thomas, John Lodge, Mike Pinder and Justin Hayward.

results.title: Why Snow Casts Such a Spell
results.abstract: Maggie O’Farrell’s “Where Snow Angels Go” and Susan Taghdis’s “The Snowman and the Sun”: Two stories of loss and renewal.

multimedia.caption: From “Where Snow Angels Go.”

results.title: Spears’s lawyer is pushing for the singer’s father to be investigated.
results.abstract: Mathew S. Rosengart, Spears’s lawyer, has accused James P. Spears of financial mismanagement, along with the estate’s former business manager, Tri Star Sports & Entertainment Group.

multimedia.caption: James P. Spears, Britney Spears’s father, in 2008.

results.title: What to Do This Weekend
results.abstract: Watch “Passing,” plan for Thanksgiving.

results.title: New Picture Books Pose Two of Life’s Biggest Questions
results.abstract: A caterpillar asks the meaning of beauty; a boy the meaning of love.

multimedia.caption: From “How Beautiful.”

results.title: Ostriches Don’t Actually Bury Their Heads in the Sand
results.abstract: Betsy Bird’s “Long Road to the Circus” blends history and zoology into a lively story for young readers.

results.title: A Charming, Poignant Middle-Grade Memoir of Soviet Russia
results.abstract: In “The Genius Under the Table,” the artist and writer Eugene Yelchin recalls his boyhood in 1970s Leningrad.

results.title: Hang It, Install It, Perform It — and Yes, Wear Your Art on Your Sleeve
results.abstract: A picture book and two middle grade books introduce young people to art mediums and their messages.
des_facet: Art of Protest: Creating, Discovering, and Activating Art for Your Revolution (Book)

multimedia.caption: From “Making a Great Exhibition.”

results.title: Portraits of Three Artists as Young Children
results.abstract: “A Boy Named Isamu,” “Roots and Wings” and “Before I Grew Up” evoke the childhoods of Isamu Noguchi, Shahzia Sikander and Giuliano Cucco.
des_facet: A Boy Named Isamu: A Story of Isamu Noguchi (Book)
Roots and Wings: How Shahzia Sikander Became an Artist (Book)

multimedia.caption: From “A Boy Named Isamu.”

results.title: Spears’s fans waited outside to hear her fate.

multimedia.caption: Supporters of Britney Spears gathered outside the Stanley Mosk Courthouse on Friday. Saige Douglas decorated a “Free Britney” Christmas tree.

results.title: 3 Middle Grade Novels Explore the Bond Between Horse and Human
results.abstract: New works of fiction by R.J. Palacio, Sharon M. Draper and J. Anderson Coats

results.title: Review: Sensation and Skin, in a Theater Housed in Bodies
results.abstract: Luciana Achugar presents the premiere of “Puro Teatro: A Spell for Utopia” at the new, improved Chocolate Factory, but its pleasures feel one-sided.
des_facet: Puro Teatro: A Spell for Utopia (Dance)
org_facet: Skirball Center for the Performing Arts

multimedia.caption: Making a theater: from left, Antonio Ramos, Molly Lieber, Sarah White-Ayón and Luciana Achugar in Achugar’s “Puro Teatro.”

results.title: Review: When Real Life Adds an Unexpected Round to the Fugue
results.abstract: Created during the pandemic, Zvi Gotheiner’s “The Art of Fugue,” performed by ZviDance at New York Live Arts, now registers as a work of recovery.

multimedia.caption: ZviDance in “Art of Fugue” at New York Live Arts in Manhattan.

results.title: Spears asked to end the conservatorship without the typical psychological evaluation.

results.title: Could the conservatorship end today?

multimedia.caption: Britney Spears in 2004.

results.title: Behold, King Tut, in All His Majesty and Mystery
results.abstract: “The Curse of the Mummy” and “King Tutankhamun Tells All!” reintroduce the boy pharaoh to young readers.

multimedia.caption: Howard Carter and an excavation foreman with King Tutankhamun’s coffin.

results.title: Sonic Sensations: Picture Books About Nina Simone and Jimi Hendrix
results.abstract: “Nina,” by Traci N. Todd, and “Song for Jimi,” by Charles R. Smith Jr., spotlight Black musicians who broke sound and color barriers.
des_facet: Nina: A Story of Nina Simone (Book)
Song for Jimi: The Story of Guitar Legend Jimi Hendrix (Book)

multimedia.caption: From “Nina.”

results.title: A Different Kind of California Dreaming
results.abstract: In Gayle Forman’s “Frankie & Bug,” a bittersweet coming-of-age novel, late-1980s Venice Beach is a living, breathing character.

results.title: Who Was Beatrix Potter?
results.abstract: The illustrator Joana Avillez delves into the life story of one of her favorite children’s book authors, creator of Peter Rabbit.

results.title: Like Riding a Bike: A Middle Grade Novel Asks, What if We Do Forget How?
results.abstract: In Alejandra Algorta’s “Neverforgotten,” illustrated by Iván Rickenmann, a baker’s son loses trust in himself, and has to gain it back.

multimedia.caption: From “Neverforgotten.”

results.title: Picturing the Power of Community
results.abstract: Four invitations to reach across borders and affirm our shared humanity.

multimedia.caption: From “Bright Star.”

results.title: The First English Translation of Hayao Miyazaki’s Favorite Childhood Book
results.abstract: Genzaburo Yoshino’s novel “How Do You Live?” may be the basis for the award-winning animator’s final film.
